case_vignette: A 34-year-old man presents with an itchy rash, primarily on his arms, but also, to a lesser extent, on his face. He denies any fever or malaise, and his medical history is unremarkable. He does not take any medications and notes that he spent the previous weekend doing yardwork on his property, and the rash appeared 4 days later. Physical examination reveals several linear arrangements of papulovesicles on the dorsal and ventral aspects of his forearms with surrounding erythema.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have an itchy rash on my arms and a bit on my face.
Is the rash accompanied by fever or other systemic symptoms?
No, I don't have any fever or malaise.
What is your age and sex?
I am a 34-year-old man.
Have you recently traveled or been exposed to new environments or animals?
I spent the last weekend doing yardwork on my property.
Have you used any new soaps, lotions, or topical medications on your skin recently?
No, I haven't used any new soaps, lotions, or medications.

Have you noticed any contact with plants or insect bites before the onset of the rash?

**Final Diagnosis:** Contact dermatitis.
